definitions.definition: to become or to make something become paler or less bright

examples.text: The curtains had faded in the sun.
All colour had faded from the sky.
The sun had faded the curtains.
He was wearing faded blue jeans.

definitions.sensetop: fade awayfade from somethingfade to/into something

examples.text: Hopes of reaching an agreement seem to be fading away.
The smile faded from his face.
His voice faded to a whisper *(= gradually became quieter)*.
All other issues **fade into insignificance** compared with the struggle for survival.
Their voices faded into the distance.
It was impossible for her to fade quietly into the background.

definitions.definition: if a sports player, team, actor, etc. fades, they stop playing or performing as well as they did before

examples.text: Black faded on the final bend.
Hopes of a peace settlement were **fading fast**.

definitions.definition: to behave in a way that does not attract any attention; to disappear or hide

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘grow weak’): from Old French fader, from fade ‘dull, insipid’, probably based on a blend of Latin fatuus ‘silly, insipid’ and vapidus ‘vapid’.
